title: Euclid peers through a dark cloud’s dusty veil
summary: This shimmering view of interstellar gas and dust was captured by the European Space Agency’s Euclid space telescope. The nebula is part of a so-called dark cloud, named LDN 1641. It sits at about 1300 light-years from Earth, within a sprawling complex of dusty gas clouds where stars are being formed, in the constellation of Orion.

title: Sentinel-1D reaches orbit on Ariane 6
summary: The Sentinel-1 mission – which provides radar vision for the Copernicus Earth observation programme – has a new addition to its family of satellites, with the arrival in orbit of Sentinel-1D, the last of the groundbreaking first generation. title: What’s Happening in Space Policy November 2-8, 2025
summary: Here is SpacePolicyOnline.com’s list of space policy events for the week of November 2-8, 2025 and any insight we can offer about them. The Senate is in session this week. […]
detailed_news: This week marks the 25th anniversary of permanent occupancy of the International Space Station. The Senate is in session this week. The House continues to be in recess indefinitely except for pro forma sessions. NASA wants commercial companies to step forward with commercial space stations where NASA can be just one of many customers. At other events this week, representatives from those companies will be sharing their plans. It’s day 33 of the partial government shutdown. House Speaker Mike Johnson decided on Friday to keep the House out of legislative session for yet another week. The shutdown can only end if enough Senate Democrats/Independents decide to vote with most Republicans. There are quite a few interesting events here and overseas. There are lots of great meetings and conferences on tap this week. We highlight a few names that probably are familiar to the readers of this website. There does not appear to be a virtual option. Check back throughout the week for others we learn about later and add to our Calendar.

title: Live coverage: Commercial space station demo, data center precursor to launch on SpaceX Bandwagon mission
summary: SpaceX will fly 18 payloads to a mid-inclination orbit including an intelligence-gathering satellite for the military of South Korea. Liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station is set for 1:09 a.m. EDT (0509 UTC).
detailed_news: Bandwagon-4, is the fourth multi-customer flight to a mid-inclination orbit and the 18th mission as part of SpaceX’s small sat ride share program. The mission will use Falcon 9 first stage booster B1091, which will eventually fly as a center booster for a Falcon Heavy rocket. The 45th Weather Squadron forecast a 95 percent chance for favorable weather at liftoff with just a small chance for interference from cumulus clouds. Starcloud believes that its future space-based data centers can be “ten times cheaper than land-based options” Philip Johnston predicted that “In 10 years, nearly all new data centers will be being built in outer space” Germany-based Exolaunch is responsible for manifesting and deploying 13 out of the 18 payloads flying.
